I think some of the ideas in this expansion were fun and intriguing, but in the end it felt too overwhelming. The story tie-in was great, the enemy variety was fresh but some were excessive and unfair, and the weapon variety was way too much (seriously, who needs a combat knife AND a wrench?). Overall, I may not have enjoyed it that much, but I feel many would like the expansion of ideas from it. If you rather something more like the base game, Blue Shift would better suit you.

Half-Life: Opposing Force is the first expansion to Half-Life. Opposing Force does what any expansion to a game should do: Expand the fundamentals for an harder experience.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ The plot of the game aligns itself very well with Half Life, lacking any major plot holes.
+ While the game is on the shorter side, the game is quite difficult compared to Half Life. While Opposing Force shouldn't be seen as a very hard game - there are a couple of sections that require you to be strategic quite a bit.
+ The introduction of new weapons are neat, they all expand on the default set quite well. The Desert Eagle - for example has a slower fire rate but is more accurate compared to the pistols of Half Life.
+ The tutorial is well made, introducing new new concepts such as rope climbing while making sense for Shephard's background.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- I think the expansion is slightly on the shorter side. While I don't think it matters given the game's difficulty, learning I was near the final boss did put me off guard.
- While this is a minor con, there's a couple of moments where ally ai take a while before following you. 

Overall, I think Opposing Force is a great expansion that should be bought if someone enjoyed Half Life.

TLDR; The best Half-Life 1 Expansion Pack

This is one of the best expansion packs I've played since it's more than just a map pack, it adds new weapons, tools, and mechanics. One of the best things this expansion pack does is how it feels connected to Half-Life 1 and not just in setting and gameplay. When you play through the game you go through important story beats also mentioned in Half-Life 1, it doesn't feel like you are playing a separate adventure, more like you are surviving along-side the other protagonists. Also the gameplay loop goes really hard. A lot of fun for such a short time.

It's just not good. 
The Black Ops aren't nearly as interesting to fight as the HECU. The new aliens feel the same to fight as the Black Ops. The game is buggy in ways that while rarely game breaking are annoying. The arsenal is bloated and it makes switching to your desired weapon a pain, it also makes keeping track of which weapons you've got ammo for a lot harder. The game takes just a bit too long between health resupplies meaning you're very likely to get stuck at an annoying part with not enough health.

Doesn't hold up, also very buggy and I would constantly get stuck on elevators with the only option of a fix, being a reload. Don't expect the NPC's to do anything they are supposed to either, constantly get stuck on doors/walls, stop following for no reason, etc. As with anything Half Life, far too many people wearing rose tinted glasses when reviewing this.

Better off waiting for the guys who made Black Mesa to mod this, and give an up to date experience like they have done with Blue Shift already.

Honestly I enjoyed this more than Half-Life, since I am terrible at puzzles and Half-Life has more of those. Plus the Black-Ops are super fun to fight

I remember when I played this game back when it released. It was great, the way it expanded the half life universe was really good, new weapons, new enemies and how you could see the events of Half-Life unfold from the eyes of the enemies. 

Recently I found the original big box for the game and it reminded me of the fun I had. I wanted to replay it, but upon picking up the box i felt some really strange [b]grease[/b] on my fingers. The box was fully covered with this [b]grease[/b]! It was strange, because you would feel like that grease would belong on some very old [b]gears[/b] and not on a [b]box[/b]. The whole thing also smelt like some fat [b]software[/b] engineer!

Luckily steam has this version digitally so I don't need to touch all this [b]grease[/b]. And the game is still as good as in 1999! If you played Half-Life you should play this too! Just don't buy it boxxed from some stranger with a name like [b]Randy[/b] or something along that from craiglist, and use the digital version instead :)))
